params.text:
Add instruction-level coverage detection to kernel

Kernel can easily detect if an instruction at any particular
index has been executed or not.
Such metrics could later be translated into line-level, or
expression-level coverage.

One possible implementation would be to create a bit
string (initially filled with zeroes) where each bit would
represent a single byte of a module (following the linear order
of bytes in module's bytecode).
When an instruction is executed the kernel enables the bit
associated with this instruction.
If at the end of the program any bit was left disabled, it
would mean that it's instruction was not executed.
Bits of data would of course stay disabled.

The disassembler would then take the bytecode executable, and
the coverage dump from the kernel; map enabled bits to
instructions, and annotate the disassembled source with
information which instructions were, and which were not
executed by the kernel.
